commands.name: git init
commands.what: Initializes a new Git repository in the current directory
commands.why: Start version control for your project to track changes
commands.when: Beginning a new project or adding version control to existing code

examples.desc: Create new directory with initialized repo

mistakes: Not setting up user name and email first
commands.realWorld: Every DevOps project starts with git init - infrastructure as code, CI/CD configurations, and application source.
commands.practice: Initialize a new repository for a DevOps scripts collection

commands.name: git clone
commands.what: Creates a copy of a remote repository on your local machine
commands.why: Get a complete copy of a project including all history
commands.when: Starting work on an existing project or contributing to open source
commands.output:
Cloning into 'repo'...
remote: Enumerating objects: 156, done.
Receiving objects: 100% (156/156), 45.23 KiB, done.
mistakes: Not having SSH keys set up for private repos
commands.realWorld: Clone infrastructure repos, CI/CD templates, and team codebases to start contributing.
commands.practice: Clone a public GitHub repository to your local machine

commands.name: git add
commands.what: Adds file changes to the staging area
commands.why: Prepare changes to be included in the next commit
commands.when: After modifying files, before committing changes

examples.desc: Stage all changes in current directory
Stage all changes in src directory

commands.output:
$ git add .
$ git status
Changes to be committed:
  new file:   app.js
  modified:   config.json
mistakes: Using 'git add .' without checking what's staged
Adding files that should be in .gitignore
commands.realWorld: Stage specific files for atomic commits, prepare deployment changes.
commands.practice: Stage specific files for a commit

commands.name: git commit
commands.what: Records staged changes to the repository
commands.why: Create a permanent snapshot of your changes with a message
commands.when: After staging changes, when a logical unit of work is complete

examples.desc: Stage and commit all tracked files

commands.output:
[main abc1234] Add user authentication
 3 files changed, 150 insertions(+), 20 deletions(-)
mistakes: Committing too many unrelated changes together
Forgetting to stage changes before committing
commands.realWorld: Create atomic commits for features, document changes for team collaboration.
commands.practice: Make a commit with a descriptive message

commands.name: git push
commands.what: Uploads local commits to a remote repository
commands.why: Share your changes with the team, backup to remote
commands.when: After committing changes you want to share
commands.output:
Enumerating objects: 5, done.
Writing objects: 100% (3/3), 512 bytes, done.
To github.com:user/repo.git
   abc123..def456  main -> main
commands.realWorld: Deploy changes to shared repos, trigger CI/CD pipelines, backup code.
commands.practice: Push your local commits to a remote repository

commands.name: git pull
commands.what: Downloads and integrates remote changes into your local branch
commands.why: Get the latest changes from your team
commands.when: Before starting work, before pushing, regularly to stay updated

examples.desc: Pull with rebase instead of merge

commands.output:
remote: Enumerating objects: 5, done.
From github.com:user/repo
 * branch main -> FETCH_HEAD
Updating abc123..def456
Fast-forward
 app.js | 10 ++++++++++
mistakes: Not pulling before starting new work
Pulling without committing local changes first
commands.realWorld: Stay synced with team changes, get latest features and fixes.
commands.practice: Pull the latest changes from your remote repository

commands.name: git branch
commands.why: Manage parallel development streams, organize features
commands.when: Starting new features, organizing work, cleaning up
commands.realWorld: Create feature branches, manage release branches, organize team work.
commands.practice: Create a new feature branch from main

commands.name: git checkout
commands.why: Navigate between branches, undo file changes
commands.when: Starting work on different feature, restoring files

examples.desc: Create and switch to new branch

commands.output:
$ git checkout -b feature-login
Switched to a new branch 'feature-login'
mistakes: Losing changes by checking out files
commands.realWorld: Switch between features, restore accidentally modified files.
commands.practice: Create and switch to a new feature branch

commands.name: git merge
commands.why: Integrate completed features into main branch
commands.when: After feature is complete, during releases

examples.desc: Merge with commit even if fast-forward

commands.output:
$ git merge feature-login
Updating abc123..def456
Fast-forward
 auth.js | 50 +++++++++++
 1 file changed, 50 insertions(+)
commands.realWorld: Integrate feature branches, combine release branches, sync with main.
commands.practice: Merge a feature branch into main

commands.name: git status
commands.why: See what files have changed, what's staged, what's untracked
commands.when: Before committing, to understand current state
commands.output:
On branch main
Changes to be committed:
  new file: feature.js

Changes not staged for commit:
  modified: app.js
commands.realWorld: Verify what will be committed, check for forgotten files.
commands.practice: Check the status of your repository

commands.name: git log
commands.why: Review changes, find commits, understand project history
commands.when: Debugging, reviewing changes, finding specific commits
commands.output:
$ git log --oneline -3
abc1234 Add user authentication
def5678 Update dependencies
ghi9012 Initial commit
mistakes: Searching entire history when limits would help
commands.realWorld: Review deployment history, find when bugs were introduced, audit changes.
commands.practice: View the last 10 commits in compact format

commands.name: git stash
commands.why: Save work in progress to switch contexts quickly
commands.when: Need to switch branches but have uncommitted work
commands.output:
$ git stash
Saved working directory and index state WIP on main: abc1234 Last commit message
commands.realWorld: Quickly switch to fix urgent bugs, save incomplete work.
commands.practice: Stash your current changes and then restore them

quiz.question: What's the difference between git init and git clone?
options: No difference, they do the same thing
init creates new repo, clone copies existing remote repo
clone is for public repos, init is for private
init is deprecated, use clone instead
quiz.explanation: git init creates a new empty repository, while git clone copies an existing remote repository with all its history.
